Valens arrogated to himself the chief direction of the business. He had relieved Caecina and his army, and on that account claimed pre-eminence. The Vitellian party had certainly gained no advantage over the enemy, till the arrival of Valens gave life and vigour to the cause. If the slowness of his march was at first liable to censure, the victory that followed made ample atonement, and re- deemed the character of the general. The soldiers from the Lower Germany were to a man devoted to his interest. It was upon this occasion, according to the ge- neral opinion, that Cuecina first began to meditate the treachery, which he after- wards carried into execution. XCIV.
